children.subject:
It may have had to do with the following piece of what I wrote above:" If you were not declared as a CS/EECS major, other than for CS170 which has enough room for almost everyone on the waitlist, you were not moved into the class."

The next paragraph suggests you resubmit and the forms will be processed moving forward every three days or so.
Why is it every 3 days? Shouldn't it be every day considering the semester is so close...I thought this was the faculty's job close to the semester. Will this include weekends?
My discussion for CS186 has 16 open spots and there are only 7 people on the waitlist. I submitted my conflict form 3 days ago, why haven't I been moved into the class?

Hi all,  I'm afraid I don't have the time to continue contacting various staff across the department every time someone has an inquiry about reader, tutor, or TA hiring. Additionally, it disrupts their work each time. My advice is to just sit tight, and if you get a position, you will hear via email. If you have an exceptional circumstance, the appropriate contact information can be found online. Hopefully the head TAs for the course will be able to answer these questions.
Hi, just wondering, but does CS160 need more readers/tutors?
That is my understanding of how calcentral should work.
Did this work?? I'm worried about the same thing...

Just to make sure before I do this.

Right now I'm currently waitlisted for CS186 (got accepted as a CS major but not officially declared since I haven't gone to L&S to sign the double major forms but this shouldn't matter because this post said major standing doesn't matter after the 10th). I assume the reason why I am not being moved into CS186 automatically is because I am currently enrolled in another course that time conflicts with it. I plan to drop that other course for CS186. I just want to confirm that once I drop the other course, I will be allowed to move into CS186 off of the waitlist when the waitlist on CalCentral whenever it updates twice per day. (Assuming CS186 hasn't filled up/has open seats in lectures and in my discussion section)

Thanks!
Please read the note to which this is a follow up. It answers the question you submit here.  There are no guarantees but you would need to follow those instructions to have a chance.

I'm unable to resubmit the conflict override form as mentioned in the note because calcentral doesn't say that there's a time conflict, since the conflict is between the midterms and a lecture.  Is there a link to the conflict override form?

Ignore the calcentral conflict form.  Use the departmental conflict form -- I've added the link to that googleform above.  Also here:  https://docs.google.com/a/berkeley.edu/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeCyBzgOo9bHFWN6x8J6TbVPEwRm-XcHn7r9qkmYadJz3mi3g/viewform

I'm on the wait list for 189 and expected to get in once enrollment opened up since my section had enough seats and I'm in eecs, but right now I'm still on the wait list.  It seems like this is because I'm also enrolled in physics 7B, which I just noticed lists two midterm times that conflict with the 189 lecture.  Is there any way I can override this conflict and still get into 189?
Read the first sentence of the post...
CS160 has only 120 seats and showing only 70 filled but 0 empty? My discussion is empty why wasn't i enrolled? Should I switch to a different section?

history.content:
For every class other than CS160, (U)GSI hiring seems completed. For those classes, the waitlists are now (as of last night at 7pmish) being processed in order regardless of major standing. Once the rest of the existing seats were made available, the waitlist was processed once for majors only and then opened up to all students.  

Before that happened, all new double-majors and form submissions to cs course conflict resolution were processed once on January 10th.  If there was no room in the lecture or in the discussions one chose then you were not moved into the class. If you were not declared as a CS/EECS major, other than for CS170 which has enough room for almost everyone on the waitlist, you were not moved into the class.

Students can resubmit department conflict forms -- see https://docs.google.com/a/berkeley.edu/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeCyBzgOo9bHFWN6x8J6TbVPEwRm-XcHn7r9qkmYadJz3mi3g/viewform  -- if they like choosing sections that remain open (if any).  Since waitlists will process automatically twice a day and the forms will only be looked at every three days or so, in courses that are full or very close to full, one can no longer be very hopeful about being enrolled in most upper div courses for which there is a conflict. Backup plans are advisable.

CS160, 184, 186, and 189 have mezzanine graduate level sections that co-inhabit the same rooms/lectures.  A moderate amount additional space in the undergraduate version may be created in the next week or two if the instructor decides to move some capacity from the graduate section to the undergraduate section.  Undergraduates will (generally) not be enrolled in the graduate component of a course that has an undergraduate component.  160/260 will max out at around 220 students. Many of those additional spaces should open up by the end of this week.

------

Jan 14 additional update:

With exceptions listed below, all conflict forms have been processed.  (If a student was already enrolled, I didn't try to move them into discussions or labs they chose on that form. I also couldn't exceed unit limits to enroll students in additional classes with a conflict.)  If you were not moved in and you submitted a conflict form for any class other than 186 or 160, that request will not be looked at again. If for some reason, you think conditions have changed, please resubmit another request.

The exceptions:

 186 -- I need to talk to the new instructor -- in the final parts of the hiring process so not listed publicly so please don't ask -- before I can release any more seats from the graduate to the undergraduate section.  If you submitted a conflict form on January 9 or later for 186 it is still in the queue. 

 160 -- Due to the three lecture room/simulcast set-up in Jacobs for a class this size, this class may take a few more days to sort out. Many students in EECS/CS on the waitlist will receive emails soon off-piazza to help move more students into the class.  If space remains, non-majors will be contacted by early in this coming week.
